Check out our updated indicators for information on wildlife species at risk! http://ow.ly/10i3e6

caption_original: What should you do if you find a migratory bird’s nest? Quietly move away from it, without disturbing the surrounding vegetation. Stay away from the nesting area until nesting is completed. http://ow.ly/10keZR
caption_cleaned: What should you do if you find a migratory bird’s nest? Quietly move away from it, without disturbing the surrounding vegetation. Stay away from the nesting area until nesting is completed.

caption_original:
The Canadian Wildlife Service established that a passport for migratory birds would facilitate the migration.   This approach will accrue more accurate bird counts and opportunity to interview birds individually on migration hazards.

This is just one of the new tools being introduced by Environment and Climate Change Canada bird biologists to celebrate 100 years of Canada-U.S. Migratory Birds Conservation on this April Fools’ Day 2016.

caption_original: Have you seen a smaller, pure white Snowy Owl recently? That was a male! Female snowy owls are larger and have black spots. Males grow up to 25 inches long, while females reach up to 27 inches. The female weighs 1 pound or so more than the male. The wingspan of both male and female snowy owls ranges from 54 to 65 inches.

caption_original:
It's National Wildlife Week! As part of the ongoing commitment to conserve wildlife habitat across the country, Environment and Climate Change Canada is proud to partner with the Nature Conservancy of Canada in protecting the historic King Ranch property in southern Alberta.

The property, formerly owned by the well-known King brothers, provides important habitat for many wildlife species, including bears, cougars, elk, moose and eagles. http://ow.ly/10D0ak

caption_original: Chemical pesticides and fertilizers are sometimes used by households to get rid of unwanted plants, insect pests and to keep up the appearance of lawns and gardens. But these chemicals can have negative environmental and health effects. The good news is that indicators show that since 1994 household chemical pesticide and fertilizer use in Canada has gone down. How can you garden more sustainably? http://ow.ly/4ncpht

How can you garden more sustainably?

caption_original: Environment and Climate Change Canada’s scientists and biologists had a great week presenting at the 2016 Salish Sea Ecosystem Conference. More than 1,100 top marine science professionals, First Nations and tribal leaders, industry executives, and policymakers came together to talk about this important transboundary ecosystem. Kudos to the organizers!

caption_original:
Did you know the Lobster Bay area near Yarmouth, N.S., is the only place in Canada where you can find the Eastern Baccharis, a rare species of shrub? This species, also called the Groundseltree, is a member of the Atlantic Coastal Plains Flora, a group of flowering plants, shrubs and herbs, many of which are legally listed under the Species at Risk Act. In fact, only 3000 mature Eastern Baccharis plants exist today.

Environment and Climate Change Canada is working with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect 20 hectares of marshland on Roberts Island in Lobster Bay. These lands are not only home to the Eastern Baccharis, but also provide important habitat for water birds, including the black duck, long-tailed duck and green-winged teal. http://ow.ly/4mKjtY
caption_cleaned: Did you know the Lobster Bay area near Yarmouth, N.S., is the only place in Canada where you can find the Eastern Baccharis, a rare species of shrub? This species, also called the Groundseltree, is a member of the Atlantic Coastal Plains Flora, a group of flowering plants, shrubs and herbs, many of which are legally listed under the Species at Risk Act. In fact, only mature Eastern Baccharis plants exist today. Environment and Climate Change Canada is working with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect hectares of marshland on Roberts Island in Lobster Bay. These lands are not only home to the Eastern Baccharis, but also provide important habitat for water birds, including the black duck, long-tailed duck and green-winged teal.

caption_original: Attention, wildlife enthusiasts! Did you know that from mid-April until the end of May, an Environment and Climate Change Canada team will be taking to the skies to count the ducks and geese breeding in and around the water bodies in the St. Lawrence Lowlands? Travelling by helicopter, the observers will identify and count all the species present, including Mallards, American Black Ducks and Wood Ducks. Back in the office, the team will compile the data, which will be used to provide a portrait of Quebec’s waterfowl populations. http://ow.ly/4n9sZw
caption_cleaned: Attention, wildlife enthusiasts! Did you know that from mid-April until the end of May, an Environment and Climate Change Canada team will be taking to the skies to count the ducks and geese breeding in and around the water bodies in the St. Lawrence Lowlands? Travelling by helicopter, the observers will identify and count all the species present, including Mallards, American Black Ducks and Wood Ducks. Back in the office, the team will compile the data, which will be used to provide a portrait of Quebec’s waterfowl populations.

caption_original: Did you know that the number of protected areas in Canada continues to grow? As of the end of 2014, Canada has protected more than 1 million square km of land and freshwater, restricting its development and use, so that we can get out and enjoy these natural spaces. http://ow.ly/10i2WK

caption_original: Did you know that beavers are super engineers? They build impressive dams, canals and lodges. They may be ungainly and slow on land, but they are graceful and strong in water. And our favourite beaver, Parks Canada’s Parka, is a great entertainer as well! Happy International Beaver Day! http://ow.ly/10keCw

caption_original:
The cedar is a naturally rare species of tree in Nova Scotia and one that has been made even scarcer due to human activity. It is listed as ‘vulnerable’ under the province’s Endangered Species Act. 

Environment and Climate Change Canada is proud to partner with Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect one of the largest cedar forests in the province and one of only a handful in northern Nova Scotia. This forested area, located near the Pugwash River in Cumberland County, was secured through a private donation made possible through the Government of Canada's Ecological Gifts Program. http://ow.ly/4mZBXS
caption_cleaned: The cedar is a naturally rare species of tree in Nova Scotia and one that has been made even scarcer due to human activity. It is listed as ‘vulnerable’ under the province’s Endangered Species Act. Environment and Climate Change Canada is proud to partner with Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect one of the largest cedar forests in the province and one of only a handful in northern Nova Scotia. This forested area, located near the Pugwash River in Cumberland County, was secured through a private donation made possible through the Government of Canada's Ecological Gifts Program.

caption_original:
Help conserve turtle species at risk in Canada! Canada’s Species at Risk Act seeks to protect critical habitat from being destroyed. Areas of critical habitat are proposed in the recovery strategies for four species of turtles found in Ontario: Blanding's Turtle, Eastern Musk Turtle, Spiny Softshell and Spotted Turtle.

These areas of critical habitat may occur on or near your property. It may include lakes, rivers, streams and wetlands where the turtles are found, as well as adjacent meadows and forests.

You are invited to comment on the proposed recovery documents. 
 http://ow.ly/10gm49

These areas of critical habitat may occur on or near your property. It may include lakes, rivers, streams and wetlands where the turtles are found, as well as adjacent meadows and forests. You are invited to comment on the proposed recovery documents. 9

caption_original: Today in history: The now 100-year-old Migratory Birds Convention between Canada and the United States has helped to support a change in bird hunting from excessive to sustainable. http://ow.ly/10zE0z

caption_original:
In 2006, the Musquash Estuary on the Bay of Fundy was designated New Brunswick's only federal Marine Protected Area. Now, on the tenth anniversary of its designation, the Government of Canada is pleased to partner with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect an additional 35 hectares of this ecologically-sensitive wetlands habitat.

The Musquash Estuary is also a key point on the Atlantic Flyway, a major bird migration route. The location, remoteness and position of the Estuary wetlands provide excellent habitat for migratory sea ducks, particularly black scoter and white-winged scoter. http://ow.ly/4mZUc2
caption_cleaned: In , the Musquash Estuary on the Bay of Fundy was designated New Brunswick's only federal Marine Protected Area. The Musquash Estuary is also a key point on the Atlantic Flyway, a major bird migration route. The location, remoteness and position of the Estuary wetlands provide excellent habitat for migratory sea ducks, particularly black scoter and white-winged scoter. Uc2

caption_original:
On April 15 1972, Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau and U.S. President Richard Nixon signed the landmark Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement. 44 years later, this binational commitment to protect the Great Lakes is stronger than ever. 

On October 4-6, 2016, Canada and the United States will host the Great Lakes Forum in Toronto, Canada. You can join federal government experts in discussions on the state of the Great Lakes, and priorities for science and action, and celebrate all that makes our Great Lakes so great. Save the dates! http://ow.ly/4mK6hi
caption_cleaned: On April , Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau and U.S. President Richard Nin signed the landmark Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement. years later, this binational commitment to protect the Great Lakes is stronger than ever. On October -6, , Canada and the United States will host the Great Lakes Forum in Toronto, Canada. You can join federal government eerts in discussions on the state of the Great Lakes, and priorities for science and action, and celebrate all that makes our Great Lakes so great. Save the dates!
